d.answer_text: Create a VPC with one subnet spanning 2 zones. Create Windows server virtual instances and enable Active Directory Domain Services. Create a load balancer with auto scaling group policy to run two virtual machines.

explanation: To create a highly available and fault tolerant architecture, the servers must be deployed in 2 zones. Two server instances should be created in each zone / subnet and should be configured to allow traffic between them. Two subnets should be created - one in each zone. For this reason, choices having less than two subnets or not spanning two zones are incorrect. Load balancer and auto scaling group are not the right choice to deploy a highly available Active Directory. For this reason, the AD option using load balancers is incorrect.

explanation: Retention policies can provide immutable storage on Cloud Storage. In conjunction with Detailed audit logging mode, which logs Cloud Storage request and response details, Bucket Lock can help with regulatory and compliance requirements, such as those associated with FINRA, SEC, and CFTC. The hedge firm can add a retention policy that prohibits anyone from deleting an object for 3 years and comply with the regulation.

a.answer_text: Create an Organizational Policy with a constraint to allow external IP addresses only on the frontend Compute Engine instances.

c.answer_text: Create an Identity and Access Management (IAM) policy that maps the IT staff to the compute.networkAdmin role for the organization.

d.answer_text: Create a custom Identity and Access Management (IAM) role named GCE_FRONTEND with the compute.addresses.create permission.

question_text: For this question, refer to the EHR Healthcare case study. You are responsible for designing the Google Cloud network architecture for Google Kubernetes Engine. You want to follow Google best practices. Considering the EHR Healthcare business and technical requirements, what should you do to reduce the attack surface? (Case Study 9)

a.answer_text: Use a private cluster with a private endpoint with master authorized networks configured.

b.answer_text: Use a public cluster with firewall rules and Virtual Private Cloud (VPC) routes.

c.answer_text: Use a private cluster with a public endpoint with master authorized networks configured.

d.answer_text: Use a public cluster with master authorized networks enabled and firewall rules.

question_text: For this question, refer to the EHR Healthcare case study. EHR has single Dedicated Interconnect connection between their primary data center and Googles network. This connection satisfies EHR's network and security policies: (Case Study 9) · On-premises servers without public IP addresses need to connect to cloud resources without public IP addresses · Traffic flows from production network mgmt. servers to Compute Engine virtual machines should never traverse the public internet. You need to upgrade the EHR connection to comply with their requirements. The new connection design must support business critical needs and meet the same network and security policy requirements. What should you do?

a.answer_text: Add a new Dedicated Interconnect connection

b.answer_text: Upgrade the bandwidth on the Dedicated Interconnect connection to 100 G

c.answer_text: Add three new Cloud VPN connections

d.answer_text: Add a new Carrier Peering connection

explanation: The case does not call out the throughput being an issue. However, to achieve 99.99%, you need to have 4 connections as per Google recommendations. However, in the options only A has the option to add an additional Interconnect connection. https://cloud.google.com/network-connectivity/docs/interconnect/concepts/dedicated-overview#availability
note: This question is similar to question 234 but provides an explanation and a different correct answer. Follows the explicit answer and explanation provided here.

question_text: One of the developers on your team deployed their application in Google Container Engine with the Dockerfile below. They report that their application deployments are taking too long. You want to optimize this Dockerfile for faster deployment times without adversely affecting the app's functionality. Which two actions should you take? Choose 2 answers.

a.answer_text: Remove Python after running pip.

b.answer_text: Remove dependencies from requirements.txt.

c.answer_text: Use a slimmed-down base image like Alpine linux.

d.answer_text: Use larger machine types for your Google Container Engine node pools.

e.answer_text: Copy the source after the package dependencies (Python and pip) are installed.

question_text: Your solution is producing performance bugs in production that you did not see in staging and test environments. You want to adjust your test and deployment procedures to avoid this problem in the future. What should you do?

a.answer_text: Deploy fewer changes to production.

b.answer_text: Deploy smaller changes to production.

c.answer_text: Increase the load on your test and staging environments.

d.answer_text: Deploy changes to a small subset of users before rolling out to production.

question_text: Your company has decided to make a major revision of their API in order to create better experiences for their developers. They need to keep the old version of the API available and deployable, while allowing new customers and testers to try out the new API. They want to keep the same SSL and DNS records in place to serve both APIs. What should they do?

a.answer_text: Configure a new load balancer for the new version of the API.

b.answer_text: Reconfigure old clients to use a new endpoint for the new API.

c.answer_text: Have the old API forward traffic to the new API based on the path.

d.answer_text: Use separate backend pools for each API path behind the load balancer.

question_text: A small number of API requests to your microservices-based application take a very long time. You know that each request to the API can traverse many services. You want to know which service takes the longest in those cases. What should you do?

a.answer_text: Set timeouts on your application so that you can fail requests faster.

b.answer_text: Send custom metrics for each of your requests to Stackdriver Monitoring.

c.answer_text: Use Stackdriver Monitoring to look for insights that show when your API latencies are high.

d.answer_text: Instrument your application with Stackdnver Trace in order to break down the request latencies at each microservice.

question_text: During a high traffic portion of the day, one of your relational databases crashes, but the replica is never promoted to a master. You want to avoid this in the future. What should you do?

a.answer_text: Use a different database.

b.answer_text: Choose larger instances for your database.

c.answer_text: Create snapshots of your database more regularly.

d.answer_text: Implement routinely scheduled failovers of your databases.

question_text: Your organization requires that metrics from all applications be retained for 5 years for future analysis in possible legal proceedings. Which approach should you use?

a.answer_text: Grant the security team access to the logs in each Project.

b.answer_text: Configure Stackdriver Monitoring for all Projects, and export to BigQuery.

c.answer_text: Configure Stackdriver Monitoring for all Projects with the default retention policies.

d.answer_text: Configure Stackdriver Monitoring for all Projects, and export to Google Cloud Storage.

explanation: Overview of storage classes, price, and use cases https://cloud.google.com/storage/docs/storage- classes Why export logs? https://cloud.google.com/logging/docs/export/ StackDriver Quotas and Limits for Monitoring https://cloud.google.com/monitoring/quotas The BigQuery pricing. https://cloud.google.com/bigquery/pricing
note: The explanation provided by the source material points to Cloud Storage as the correct choice for long-term archival of metrics/logs due to cost-effectiveness, implying direct export from Stackdriver (Cloud Logging) to GCS is the standard practice for long retention periods beyond default limits.

question_text: Your company has decided to build a backup replica of their on-premises user authentication PostgreSQL database on Google Cloud Platform. The database is 4 TB, and large updates are frequent. Replication requires private address space communication. Which networking approach should you use?

a.answer_text: Google Cloud Dedicated Interconnect

b.answer_text: Google Cloud VPN connected to the data center network

c.answer_text: A NAT and TLS translation gateway installed on-premises

d.answer_text: A Google Compute Engine instance with a VPN server installed connected to the data center network

note: Dedicated Interconnect provides high bandwidth and private connectivity, suitable for large database replication with frequent updates and private communication requirements. Cloud VPN is generally lower bandwidth and higher latency.

question_text: Your company is forecasting a sharp increase in the number and size of Apache Spark and Hadoop jobs being run on your local datacenter You want to utilize the cloud to help you scale this upcoming demand with the least amount of operations work and code change. Which product should you use?

a.answer_text: Google Cloud Dataflow

b.answer_text: Google Cloud Dataproc

c.answer_text: Google Compute Engine

d.answer_text: Google Container Engine

explanation: Google Cloud Dataproc is a fast, easy-to-use, low-cost and fully managed service that lets you run the Apache Spark and Apache Hadoop ecosystem on Google Cloud Platform. Cloud Dataproc provisions big or small clusters rapidly, supports many popular job types, and is integrated with other Google Cloud Platform services, such as Google Cloud Storage and Stackdriver Logging, thus helping you reduce TCO.

question_text: Your company's test suite is a custom C++ application that runs tests throughout each day on Linux virtual machines. The full test suite takes several hours to complete, running on a limited number of on premises servers reserved for testing. Your company wants to move the testing infrastructure to the cloud, to reduce the amount of time it takes to fully test a change to the system, while changing the tests as little as possible. Which cloud infrastructure should you recommend?

a.answer_text: Google Compute Engine unmanaged instance groups and Network Load Balancer

b.answer_text: Google Compute Engine managed instance groups with auto-scaling

c.answer_text: Google Cloud Dataproc to run Apache Hadoop jobs to process each test

d.answer_text: Google App Engine with Google Stackdriver for logging

explanation: https://cloud.google.com/compute/docs/instance-groups/ Google Compute Engine enables users to launch virtual machines (VMs) on demand. VMs can be launched from the standard images or custom images created by users. Managed instance groups offer autoscaling capabilities that allow you to automatically add or remove instances from a managed instance group based on increases or decreases in load. Autoscaling helps your applications gracefully handle increases in traffic and reduces cost when the need for resources is lower.

question_text: Auditors visit your teams every 12 months and ask to review all the Google Cloud Identity and Access Management (Cloud IAM) policy changes in the previous 12 months. You want to streamline and expedite the analysis and audit process. What should you do?

a.answer_text: Create custom Google Stackdriver alerts and send them to the auditor.

b.answer_text: Enable Logging export to Google BigQuery and use ACLs and views to scope the data shared with the auditor.

c.answer_text: Use cloud functions to transfer log entries to Google Cloud SQL and use ACLS and views to limit an auditor's view.

d.answer_text: Enable Google Cloud Storage (GCS) log export to audit logs Into a GCS bucket and delegate access to the bucket.

explanation: Export the logs to Google Cloud Storage bucket - Archive Storage, as it will not be used for 1 year, price for which is $0.004 per GB per Month. The price for long term storage in BigQuery is $0.01 per GB per Month (250% more). Also for analysis purpose, whenever Auditors are there(once per year), you can use BigQuery and use GCS bucket as external data source. BigQuery supports querying Cloud Storage data from these storage classes: Standard Nearline Coldline Archive

question_text: You are designing a large distributed application with 30 microservices. Each of your distributed microservices needs to connect to a database back-end. You want to store the credentials securely. Where should you store the credentials?

a.answer_text: In the source code

b.answer_text: In an environment variable

c.answer_text: In a secret management system

d.answer_text: In a config file that has restricted access through ACLs

question_text: The operations manager asks you for a list of recommended practices that she should consider when migrating a J2EE application to the cloud. Which three practices should you recommend? Choose 3 answers

a.answer_text: Port the application code to run on Google App Engine.

b.answer_text: Integrate Cloud Dataflow into the application to capture real-time metrics.

c.answer_text: Instrument the application with a monitoring tool like Stackdriver Debugger.

d.answer_text: Select an automation framework to reliably provision the cloud infrastructure.

e.answer_text: Deploy a continuous integration tool with automated testing in a staging environment.

f.answer_text: Migrate from MySQL to a managed NoSQL database like Google Cloud Datastore or Bigtable.

note: The phrasing 'Choose 3 answers' dictates multiple correct options.

question_text: You want to enable your running Google Kubernetes Engine cluster to scale as demand for your application changes. What should you do?

a.answer_text: Add additional nodes to your Kubernetes Engine cluster using the following command:gcloud container clusters resizeCLUSTER_Name -size 10

b.answer_text: Add a tag to the instances in the cluster with the following command:gcloud compute instances add-tagsINSTANCE - -tags enable-autoscaling max-nodes-10

c.answer_text: Update the existing Kubernetes Engine cluster with the following command:gcloud alpha container clustersupdate mycluster - -enable-autoscaling - -min-nodes=1 - -max-nodes=10

d.answer_text: Create a new Kubernetes Engine cluster with the following command:gcloud alpha container clusterscreate mycluster - -enable-autoscaling - -min-nodes=1 - -max-nodes=10and redeploy your application

explanation: https://cloud.google.com/kubernetes-engine/docs/concepts/cluster-autoscaler To enable autoscaling for an existing node pool, run the following command: gcloud container clusters update [CLUSTER_NAME] --enable-autoscaling \ --min-nodes 1 --max-nodes 10 --zone [COMPUTE_ZONE] --node-pool default-pool
note: The command shown in the provided option C (and the explanation's example) uses `gcloud alpha container clusters update` which might be outdated. However, following the provided correct answer. The stable command now would generally be `gcloud container clusters update`.

question_text: A lead engineer wrote a custom tool that deploys virtual machines in the legacy data center. He wants to migrate the custom tool to the new cloud environment You want to advocate for the adoption of Google Cloud Deployment Manager What are two business risks of migrating to Cloud Deployment Manager? Choose 2 answers

a.answer_text: Cloud Deployment Manager uses Python.

b.answer_text: Cloud Deployment Manager APIs could be deprecated in the future.

c.answer_text: Cloud Deployment Manager is unfamiliar to the company's engineers.

d.answer_text: Cloud Deployment Manager requires a Google APIs service account to run.

e.answer_text: Cloud Deployment Manager can be used to permanently delete cloud resources.

f.answer_text: Cloud Deployment Manager only supports automation of Google Cloud resources.

note: Challenges with new technology adoption (unfamiliarity) and vendor lock-in (Google Cloud only) are common business risks.

question_text: Your company just finished a rapid lift and shift to Google Compute Engine for your compute needs. You have another 9 months to design and deploy a more cloud-native solution. Specifically, you want a system that is no-ops and auto-scaling. Which two compute products should you choose? Choose 2 answers

a.answer_text: Compute Engine with containers

b.answer_text: Google Kubernetes Engine with containers

c.answer_text: Google App Engine Standard Environment

d.answer_text: Compute Engine with custom instance types

e.answer_text: Compute Engine with managed instance groups

explanation: B: With Container Engine, Google will automatically deploy your cluster for you, update, patch, secure the nodes. Kubernetes Engine's cluster autoscaler automatically resizes clusters based on the demands of the workloads you want to run. C: Solutions like Datastore, BigQuery, AppEngine, etc are truly NoOps. App Engine by default scales the number of instances running up and down to match the load, thus providing consistent performance for your app at all times while minimizing idle instances and thus reducing cost. Note: At a high level, NoOps means that there is no infrastructure to build out and manage during usage of the platform. Typically, the compromise you make with NoOps is that you lose control of the underlying infrastructure.

question_text: A development manager is building a new application He asks you to review his requirements and identify what cloud technologies he can use to meet them. The application must 1. Be based on open-source technology for cloud portability 2. Dynamically scale compute capacity based on demand 3. Support continuous software delivery 4. Run multiple segregated copies of the same application stack 5. Deploy application bundles using dynamic templates 6. Route network traffic to specific services based on URL. Which combination of technologies will meet all of his requirements?

a.answer_text: Google Container Engine, Jenkins, and Helm

b.answer_text: Google Container Engine and Cloud Load Balancing

c.answer_text: Google Compute Engine and Cloud Deployment Manager

d.answer_text: Google Compute Engine, Jenkins, and Cloud Load Balancing

note: Open-source (Kubernetes/GKE, Jenkins, Helm), dynamic scaling (GKE), continuous delivery (Jenkins), segregated copies (Kubernetes deployments/namespaces), dynamic templates (Helm charts), URL routing (GKE Ingress/LoadBalancer.

question_text: Your marketing department wants to send out a promotional email campaign. The development team wants to minimize direct operation management. They project a wide range of possible customer responses, from 100 to 500,000 click-throughs per day. The link leads to a simple website that explains the promotion and collects user information and preferences. Which infrastructure should you recommend? (CHOOSE TWO)

a.answer_text: Use Google App Engine to serve the website and Google Cloud Datastore to store user data.

b.answer_text: Use a Google Container Engine cluster to serve the website and store data to persistent disk.

c.answer_text: Use a managed instance group to serve the website and Google Cloud Bigtable to store user data.

d.answer_text: Use a single compute Engine virtual machine (VM) to host a web server, backed by Google Cloud SQL.

note: App Engine (standard environment) is serverless and auto-scales, fitting 'minimize direct operation management' and wide demand range, with Datastore being a flexible NoSQL database. Managed Instance Groups with autoscaling also fit the compute scaling requirement, and Bigtable is suitable for large-scale key-value data with high throughput.

question_text: One of your primary business objectives is being able to trust the data stored in your application. You want to log all changes to the application data How can you design your logging system to verify authenticity of your logs?

a.answer_text: Write the log concurrently in the cloud and on premises.

b.answer_text: Use a SQL database and limit who can modify the log table.

c.answer_text: Digitally sign each timestamp and log entry and store the signature.

d.answer_text: Create a JSON dump of each log entry and store it in Google Cloud Storage.

note: Digital signing ensures non-repudiation and integrity verification, crucial for trusting log authenticity.

question_text: You have created several preemptible Linux virtual machine instances using Google Compute Engine. You want to properly shut down your application before the virtual machines are preempted. What should you do?

a.answer_text: Create a shutdown script named k99.shutdown in the /etc/rc.6.d/ directory.

b.answer_text: Create a shutdown script registered as a xinetd service in Linux and configure a Stackdnver endpoint check to call the service.

c.answer_text: Create a shutdown script and use it as the value for a new metadata entry with the key shutdown- script in the Cloud Platform Console when you create the new virtual machine instance.

d.answer_text: Create a shutdown script, registered as a xinetd service in Linux, and use the gcloud compute instances add-metadata command to specify the service URL as the value for a new metadata entry with the key shutdown-script-url

note: Compute Engine provides a `shutdown-script` metadata key specifically for handling graceful shutdowns on VM termination, which is especially useful for preemptible VMs.

question_text: A production database virtual machine on Google Compute Engine has an ext4-formatted persistent disk for data files The database is about to run out of storage space How can you remediate the problem with the least amount of downtime?

a.answer_text: In the Cloud Platform Console, increase the size of the persistent disk and use the resize2fs command in Linux.

b.answer_text: Shut down the virtual machine, use the Cloud Platform Console to increase the persistent disk size, then restart the virtual machine.

c.answer_text: In the Cloud Platform Console, increase the size of the persistent disk and verify the new space is ready to use with the fdisk command in Linux.

d.answer_text: In the Cloud Platform Console, create a new persistent disk attached to the virtual machine, format and mount it, and configure the database service to move the files to the new disk.

e.answer_text: In the Cloud Platform Console, create a snapshot of the persistent disk, restore the snapshot to a new larger disk, unmount the old disk, mount the new disk, and restart the database service.

note: Persistent disks can often be resized while the VM is running, and then the filesystem needs to be extended inside the guest OS (e.g., with `resize2fs` for ext4) to utilize the new space, minimizing downtime.

question_text: Your organization has a 3-tier web application deployed in the same network on Google Cloud Platform. Each tier (web, API, and database) scales independently of the others Network traffic should flow through the web to the API tier and then on to the database tier. Traffic should not flow between the web and the database tier. How should you configure the network?

a.answer_text: Add each tier to a different subnetwork.

b.answer_text: Set up software based firewalls on individual VMs.

c.answer_text: Add tags to each tier and set up routes to allow the desired traffic flow.

d.answer_text: Add tags to each tier and set up firewall rules to allow the desired traffic flow.

explanation: Google Cloud Platform(GCP) enforces firewall rules through rules and tags. GCP rules and tags can be defined once and used across all regions.

question_text: To reduce costs, the Director of Engineering has required all developers to move their development infrastructure resources from on-premises virtual machines (VMs) to Google Cloud Platform. These resources go through multiple start/stop events during the day and require state to persist. You have been asked to design the process of running a development environment in Google Cloud while providing cost visibility to the finance department. Which two steps should you take? Choose 2 answers

a.answer_text: Use the --no-auto-delete flag on all persistent disks and stop the VM.

b.answer_text: Use the -auto-delete flag on all persistent disks and terminate the VM.

c.answer_text: Apply VM CPU utilization label and include it in the BigQuery billing export.

d.answer_text: Use Google BigQuery billing export and labels to associate cost to groups.

e.answer_text: Store all state into local SSD, snapshot the persistent disks, and terminate the VM.

f.answer_text: Store all state in Google Cloud Storage, snapshot the persistent disks, and terminate the VM.

hint: For cost visibility, consider billing exports and resource tagging. For persistent state on VMs, ensure disks are not automatically deleted.

question_text: Your company's user-feedback portal comprises a standard LAMP stack replicated across two zones. It is deployed in the us-central1 region and uses autoscaled managed instance groups on all layers, except the database. Currently, only a small group of select customers have access to the portal. The portal meets a 99.99% availability SLA under these conditions However next quarter, your company will be making the portal available to all users, including unauthenticated users. You need to develop a resiliency testing strategy to ensure the system maintains the SLA once they introduce additional user load. What should you do?

a.answer_text: Capture existing users input, and replay captured user load until autoscale is triggered on all layers. At the same time, terminate all resources in one of the zones.

b.answer_text: Create synthetic random user input, replay synthetic load until autoscale logic is triggered on at least one layer, and introduce "chaos" to the system by terminating random resources on both zones.

c.answer_text: Expose the new system to a larger group of users, and increase group ' size each day until autoscale logic is tnggered on all layers. At the same time, terminate random resources on both zones.

d.answer_text: Capture existing users input, and replay captured user load until resource utilization crosses 80%. Also, derive estimated number of users based on existing users usage of the app, and deploy enough resources to handle 200% of expected load.

hint: To test system resilience under load and failure, consider combining realistic load testing with failure injection (chaos engineering).

question_text: Your customer is moving an existing corporate application to Google Cloud Platform from an on- premises data center. The business owners require minimal user disruption. There are strict security team requirements for storing passwords. What authentication strategy should they use?

a.answer_text: Use G Suite Password Sync to replicate passwords into Google.

b.answer_text: Federate authentication via SAML 2.0 to the existing Identity Provider.

c.answer_text: Provision users in Google using the Google Cloud Directory Sync tool.

d.answer_text: Ask users to set their Google password to match their corporate password.

hint: For strict password security and minimal disruption during migration, consider federating identity to an existing on-premises system.

question_text: Your customer is moving their corporate applications to Google Cloud Platform. The security team wants detailed visibility of all projects in the organization. You provision the Google Cloud Resource Manager and set up yourself as the org admin. What Google Cloud Identity and Access Management (Cloud IAM) roles should you give to the security team'?

a.answer_text: Org viewer, project owner

b.answer_text: Org viewer, project viewer

c.answer_text: Org admin, project browser

d.answer_text: Project owner, network admin

hint: For visibility without modification rights, consider viewer roles at both the organization and project levels.

question_text: Your company places a high value on being responsive and meeting customer needs quickly. Their primary business objectives are release speed and agility. You want to reduce the chance of security errors being accidentally introduced. Which two actions can you take? Choose 2 answers

a.answer_text: Ensure every code check-in is peer reviewed by a security SME.

b.answer_text: Use source code security analyzers as part of the CI/CD pipeline.

c.answer_text: Ensure you have stubs to unit test all interfaces between components.

d.answer_text: Enable code signing and a trusted binary repository integrated with your CI/CD pipeline.

e.answer_text: Run a vulnerability security scanner as part of your continuous-integration /continuous-delivery (CI/CD) pipeline.

hint: To reduce security errors with speed and agility, focus on automating security checks within your development and deployment workflows.

question_text: You are helping the QA team to roll out a new load-testing tool to test the scalability of your primary cloud services that run on Google Compute Engine with Cloud Bigtable. Which three requirements should they include? Choose 3 answers

a.answer_text: Ensure that the load tests validate the performance of Cloud Bigtable.

b.answer_text: Create a separate Google Cloud project to use for the load-testing environment.

c.answer_text: Schedule the load-testing tool to regularly run against the production environment.

d.answer_text: Ensure all third-party systems your services use are capable of handling high load.

e.answer_text: Instrument the production services to record every transaction for replay by the load-testing tool.

f.answer_text: Instrument the load-testing tool and the target services with detailed logging and metrics collection.

hint: When load testing complex cloud systems, consider isolating the test environment, including all critical components in the test scope, and meticulously collecting performance data.

question_text: You want to make a copy of a production Linux virtual machine in the US-Central region. You want to manage and replace the copy easily if there are changes on the production virtual machine. You will deploy the copy as a new instances in a different project in the US-East region. What steps must you take?

a.answer_text: Use the Linux dd and netcat command to copy and stream the root disk contents to a new virtual machine instance in the US-East region.

b.answer_text: Create a snapshot of the root disk and select the snapshot as the root disk when you create a new virtual machine instance in the US-East region.

c.answer_text: Create an image file from the root disk with Linux dd command, create a new disk from the image file, and use it to create a new virtual machine instance in the US-East region

d.answer_text: Create a snapshot of the root disk, create an image file in Google Cloud Storage from the snapshot, and create a new virtual machine instance in the US-East region using the image file for the root disk.

hint: For easily managing and deploying copies of VMs across regions/projects, consider using VM disk snapshots to create a custom image stored in Cloud Storage.

question_text: Your company runs several databases on a single MySQL instance. They need to take backups of a specific database at regular intervals. The backup activity needs to complete as quickly as possible and cannot be allowed to impact disk performance. How should you configure the storage?

a.answer_text: Configure a cron job to use the gcloud tool to take regular backups using persistent disk snapshots.

b.answer_text: Mount a Local SSD volume as the backup location. After the backup is complete, use gsutil to move the backup to Google Cloud Storage.

c.answer_text: Use gcsfuse to mount a Google Cloud Storage bucket as a volume directly on the instance and write backups to the mounted location using mysqldump

d.answer_text: Mount additional persistent disk volumes onto each virtual machine (VM) instance in a RAID10 array and use LVM to create snapshots to send to Cloud Storage.

hint: To minimize backup impact on active disk performance, consider using a very high-speed temporary storage during the backup process.

question_text: You deploy your custom Java application to Google App Engine. It fails to deploy and gives you the following stack trace. What should you do?

a.answer_text: Upload missing JAR files and redeploy your application.

b.answer_text: Digitally sign all of your JAR files and redeploy your application

c.answer_text: Recompile the CLoakedServlet class using and MD5 hash instead of SHA1

hint: If a Java application deployment fails on App Engine, especially with security-related errors in the stack trace, consider issues with JAR signing.

question_text: The application reliability team at your company has added a debug feature to their backend service to send all server events to Google Cloud Storage for eventual analysis. The event records are at least 50 KB and at most 15 MB and are expected to peak at 3,000 events per second. You want to minimize data loss. Which process should you implement?

a.answer_text: · Append metadata to file body. · Compress individual files. · Name files with serverName-Timestamp. · Create a new bucket if bucket is older than 1 hour and save individual files to the new bucket. Otherwise, save files to existing bucket

b.answer_text: · Batch every 10,000 events with a single manifest file for metadata. · Compress event files and manifest file into a single archive file. · Name files using serverName-EventSequence. · Create a new bucket if bucket is older than 1 day and save the single archive file to the new bucket. Otherwise, save the single archive file to existing bucket.

c.answer_text: · Compress individual files. · Name files with serverName-EventSequence. · Save files to one bucket · Set custom metadata headers for each object after saving.

d.answer_text: · Append metadata to file body. · Compress individual files. · Name files with a random prefix pattern. · Save files to one bucket

explanation: In order to maintain a high request rate, avoid using sequential names. Using completely random object names will give you the best load distribution. Randomness after a common prefix is effective under the prefix
hint: For high-volume writes to Cloud Storage, naming objects with random prefixes helps distribute the load and prevents hot spots.

question_text: A lead software engineer tells you that his new application design uses websockets and HTTP sessions that are not distributed across the web servers. You want to help him ensure his application will run property on Google Cloud Platform. What should you do?

a.answer_text: Help the engineer to convert his websocket code to use HTTP streaming.

b.answer_text: Review the encryption requirements for websocket connections with the security team.

c.answer_text: Meet with the cloud operations team and the engineer to discuss load balancer options.

d.answer_text: Help the engineer redesign the application to use a distributed user session service that does not rely on websockets and HTTP sessions.

explanation: Google Cloud Platform (GCP) HTTP(S) load balancing provides global load balancing for HTTP(S) requests destined for your instances. The HTTP(S) load balancer has native support for the WebSocket protocol. Incorrect Answers: A: HTTP server push, also known as HTTP streaming, is a client-server communication pattern that sends information from an HTTP server to a client asynchronously, without a client request. A server push architecture is especially effective for highly interactive web or mobile applications, where one or more clients need to receive continuous information from the server.
hint: For applications with sticky sessions or WebSockets, proper load balancer configuration is crucial for ensuring traffic is routed to the correct backend instance.

question_text: You want to enable your running Google Container Engine cluster to scale as demand for your application changes. What should you do?

a.answer_text: Add additional nodes to your Container Engine cluster using the following command: gcloud container clusters resize CLUSTER_NAME --size 10

b.answer_text: Add a tag to the instances in the cluster with the following command: gcloud compute instances add-tags INSTANCE --tags enable --autoscaling max-nodes-10

c.answer_text: Update the existing Container Engine cluster with the following command: gcloud alpha container clusters update mycluster --enable-autoscaling --min-nodes=1 --max- nodes=10

d.answer_text: Create a new Container Engine cluster with the following command: gcloud alpha container clusters create mycluster --enable-autocaling --min-nodes=1 --max-nodes=10 and redeploy your application.

explanation: The correct answer is B because it uses the `gcloud compute instances add-tags` command to *enable autoscaling* on the cluster nodes, which is the mechanism for dynamic scaling in Google Kubernetes Engine (GKE). Options A, C, and D are incorrect because they either manually resize nodes or attempt to configure autoscaling with incorrect commands or alpha features that are not the standard way to achieve this.
hint: Consider how your cluster can dynamically adjust its size to meet fluctuating application needs. Think about the built-in mechanisms for managing resource allocation within GKE.

question_text: You created a pipeline that can deploy your source code changes to your infrastructure in instance groups for self healing. One of the changes negatively affects your key performance indicator. You are not sure how to fix it and investigation could take up to a week. What should you do?

a.answer_text: Log in to a server, and iterate a fix locally

b.answer_text: Change the instance group template to the previous one, and delete all instances.

c.answer_text: Revert the source code change and rerun the deployment pipeline

d.answer_text: Log into the servers with the bad code change, and swap in the previous code

hint: In an automated deployment pipeline, the most consistent and reliable way to roll back a bad change is to revert it in source control and rerun the pipeline.

question_text: A recent audit that a new network was created in Your GCP project. In this network, a GCE instance has an SSH port open the world. You want to discover this network's origin. What should you do?

a.answer_text: Search for Create VM entry in the Stackdriver alerting console.

b.answer_text: Navigate to the Activity page in the Home section. Set category to Data Access and search for Create VM entry.

c.answer_text: In the logging section of the console, specify GCE Network as the logging section. Search for the Create Insert entry.

d.answer_text: Connect to the GCE instance using project SSH Keys. Identify previous logins in system logs, and match these with the project owners list.

hint: To trace the origin of resource creation and configuration changes in GCP, use Cloud Audit Logs in Cloud Logging.

question_text: As part of implementing their disaster recovery plan, your company is trying to replicate their production MySQL database from their private data center to their GCP project using a Google Cloud VPN connection. They are experiencing latency issues and a small amount of packet loss that is disrupting the replication. What should they do?

a.answer_text: Configure their replication to use UDP.

b.answer_text: Configure a Google Cloud Dedicated Interconnect.

c.answer_text: Restore their database daily using Google Cloud SQL.

d.answer_text: Add additional VPN connections and load balance them.

e.answer_text: Send the replicated transaction to Google Cloud Pub/Sub.

hint: For critical, high-volume, low-latency, and reliable connectivity between on-premises and GCP, especially for database replication, a direct network interconnect often outperforms VPN over the public internet.

question_text: Your organization has stored sensitive data in a Cloud Storage bucket. For regulatory reasons, your company must be able to rotate the encryption key used to encrypt the data in the bucket. The data will be processed in Dataproc. You want to follow Google-recommended practices for security. What should you do?

a.answer_text: Create a key with Cloud Key Management Service (KMS). Encrypt the data using the encrypt method of Cloud KMS.

b.answer_text: Create a key with Cloud Key Management Service (KMS). Set the encryption key on the bucket to the Cloud KMS key.

c.answer_text: Generate a GPG key pair. Encrypt the data using the GPG key. Upload the encrypted data to the bucket.

d.answer_text: Generate an AES-256 encryption key. Encrypt the data in the bucket using the customer-supplied encryption keys feature.

hint: For rotating encryption keys for sensitive data in Cloud Storage while maintaining integration with other GCP services, use Customer-Managed Encryption Keys (CMEK) with Cloud KMS.

question_text: Your company has an application running on App Engine that allows users to upload music files and share them with other people. You want to allow users to upload files directly into Cloud Storage from their browser session. The payload should not be passed through the backend. What should you do?

a.answer_text: 1. Set a CORS configuration in the target Cloud Storage bucket where the base URL of the App Engine application is an allowed origin. 2. Use the Cloud Storage Signed URL feature to generate a POST URL.

b.answer_text: 1. Set a CORS configuration in the target Cloud Storage bucket where the base URL of the App Engine application is an allowed origin. 2. Assign the Cloud Storage WRITER role to users who upload files.

c.answer_text: 1. Use the Cloud Storage Signed URL feature to generate a POST URL. 2. Use App Engine default credentials to sign requests against Cloud Storage.

d.answer_text: 1. Assign the Cloud Storage WRITER role to users who upload files. 2. Use App Engine default credentials to sign requests against Cloud Storage.

hint: To enable direct browser uploads to Cloud Storage without passing through your backend, use Signed URLs and configure CORS.

question_text: Your company has an application running on Compute Engine that allows users to play their favorite music. There are a fixed number of instances. Files are stored in Cloud Storage, and data is streamed directly to users. Users are reporting that they sometimes need to attempt to play popular songs multiple times before they are successful. You need to improve the performance of the application. What should you do?

a.answer_text: 1. Mount the Cloud Storage bucket using gcsfuse on all backend Compute Engine instances. 2. Serve music files directly from the backend Compute Engine instance.

b.answer_text: 1. Create a Cloud Filestore NFS volume and attach it to the backend Compute Engine instances. 2. Download popular songs in Cloud Filestore. 3. Serve music files directly from the backend Compute Engine instance.

c.answer_text: 1. Copy popular songs into CloudSQL as a blob. 2. Update application code to retrieve data from CloudSQL when Cloud Storage is overloaded.

d.answer_text: 1. Create a managed instance group with Compute Engine instances. 2. Create a global load balancer and —ג :configure it with two backends —ג Managed instance group ‹ ‹ Cloud Storage bucket 3. Enable Cloud CDN on the bucket backend.

hint: For streaming popular static content like music, especially from Cloud Storage, a Content Delivery Network (CDN) can significantly improve performance and reduce load.

question_text: You are designing a Data Warehouse on Google Cloud and want to store sensitive data in BigQuery. Your company requires you to generate the encryption keys outside of Google Cloud. You need to implement a solution. What should you do?

a.answer_text: Generate a new key in Cloud Key Management Service (Cloud KMS). Store all data in Cloud Storage using the customer-managed key option and select the created key. Set up a Dataflow pipeline to decrypt the data and to store it in a new BigQuery dataset.

b.answer_text: Generate a new key in Cloud KMS. Create a dataset in BigQuery using the customer-managed key option and select the created key.

c.answer_text: Import a key in Cloud KMS. Store all data in Cloud Storage using the customer-managed key option and select the created key. Set up a Dataflow pipeline to decrypt the data and to store it in a new BigQuery dataset.

d.answer_text: Import a key in Cloud KMS. Create a dataset in BigQuery using the customer-supplied key option and select the created key.

hint: When external key generation is required for BigQuery encryption, utilize Cloud KMS to import the key and then apply it as a Customer-Managed Encryption Key (CMEK) to your BigQuery dataset.

question_text: You are running a cluster on Kubernetes Engine (GKE) to serve a web application. Users are reporting that a specific part of the application is not responding anymore. You notice that all pods of your deployment keep restarting after 2 seconds. The application writes logs to standard output. You want to inspect the logs to find the cause of the issue. Which approach can you take?

a.answer_text: Review the Stackdriver logs for each Compute Engine instance that is serving as a node in the cluster.

b.answer_text: Review the Stackdriver logs for the specific GKE container that is serving the unresponsive part of the application.

c.answer_text: Connect to the cluster using gcloud credentials and connect to a container in one of the pods to read the logs.

d.answer_text: Review the Serial Port logs for each Compute Engine instance that is serving as a node in the cluster.

hint: For application logs from Kubernetes pods, especially for rapidly restarting containers, centralized logging services like Cloud Logging are the most effective tool.

question_text: Your company has a Google Cloud project that uses BigQuery for data warehousing. They have a VPN tunnel between the on-premises environment and Google Cloud that is configured with Cloud VPN. The security team wants to avoid data exfiltration by malicious insiders, compromised code, and accidental oversharing. What should they do?

a.answer_text: Configure Private Google Access for on-premises only.

b.answer_text: Perform the following tasks: 1. Create a service account. 2. Give the BigQuery JobUser role and Storage Reader role to the service account. 3. Remove all other IAM access from the project.

c.answer_text: Configure VPC Service Controls and configure Private Google Access.

d.answer_text: Configure Private Google Access.

hint: To prevent data exfiltration from sensitive services like BigQuery, especially in hybrid environments, consider using VPC Service Controls to establish security perimeters.

question_text: You are managing several internal applications that are deployed on Compute Engine. Business users inform you that an application has become very slow over the past few days. You want to find the underlying cause in order to solve the problem. What should you do first?

a.answer_text: Inspect the logs and metrics from the instances in Cloud Logging and Cloud Monitoring.

b.answer_text: Change the Compute Engine Instances behind the application to a machine type with more CPU and memory.

c.answer_text: Restore a backup of the application database from a time before the application became slow.

d.answer_text: Deploy the applications on a managed instance group with autoscaling enabled. Add a load balancer in front of the managed instance group, and have the users connect to the IP of the load balancer.

hint: The primary first step in troubleshooting any application performance issue is always to collect and analyze diagnostic data, including logs and metrics.

question_text: You have deployed an application on Anthos clusters (formerly Anthos GKE). According to the SRE practices at your company, you need to be alerted if request latency is above a certain threshold for a specified amount of time. What should you do?

a.answer_text: Install Anthos Service Mesh on your cluster. Use the Google Cloud Console to define a Service Level Objective (SLO), and create an alerting policy based on this SLO.

b.answer_text: Enable the Cloud Trace API on your project, and use Cloud Monitoring Alerts to send an alert based on the Cloud Trace metrics.

c.answer_text: Use Cloud Profiler to follow up the request latency. Create a custom metric in Cloud Monitoring based on the results of Cloud Profiler, and create an Alerting policy in case this metric exceeds the threshold.

d.answer_text: Configure Anthos Config Management on your cluster, and create a yaml file that defines the SLO and alerting policy you want to deploy in your cluster.

hint: For SRE-driven alerting on service latency in Anthos GKE, consider leveraging service mesh metrics and defining Service Level Objectives (SLOs) in Cloud Monitoring.

question_text: Your company has an application running as a Deployment in a Google Kubernetes Engine (GKE) cluster. When releasing new versions of the application via a rolling deployment, the team has been causing outages. The root cause of the outages is misconfigurations with parameters that are only used in production. You want to put preventive measures for this in the platform to prevent outages. What should you do?

a.answer_text: Configure liveness and readiness probes in the Pod specification.

b.answer_text: Configure health checks on the managed instance group.

c.answer_text: Create a Scheduled Task to check whether the application is available.

d.answer_text: Configure an uptime alert in Cloud Monitoring.

hint: Liveness and readiness probes are crucial for Kubernetes deployments to ensure that new pods are healthy and ready to serve traffic before being integrated into the service, preventing outages during rolling updates.

question_text: Your company has a stateless web API that performs scientific calculations. The web API runs on a single Google Kubernetes Engine (GKE) cluster. The cluster is currently deployed in us-central1. Your company has expanded to offer your API to customers in Asia. You want to reduce the latency for users in Asia. What should you do?

a.answer_text: Create a second GKE cluster in asia-southeast1, and expose both APIs using a Service of type LoadBalancer. Add the public IPs to the Cloud DNS zone.

b.answer_text: Use a global HTTP(s) load balancer with Cloud CDN enabled.

c.answer_text: Create a second GKE cluster in asia-southeast1, and use kubemci to create a global HTTP(s) load balancer.

d.answer_text: Increase the memory and CPU allocated to the application in the cluster.

hint: To reduce latency for a global user base accessing APIs served from multiple GKE clusters in different regions, consider a global (Multi-Cluster) HTTP(S) Load Balancer.

question_text: Your company has an application running as a Deployment in a Google Kubernetes Engine (GKE) cluster. You have separate clusters for development, staging, and production. You have discovered that the team is able to deploy a Docker image to the production cluster without first testing the deployment in development and then staging. You want to allow the team to have autonomy but want to prevent this from happening. You want a Google Cloud solution that can be implemented quickly with minimal effort. What should you do?

a.answer_text: Configure a Kubernetes lifecycle hook to prevent the container from starting if it is not approved for usage in the given environment.

b.answer_text: Implement a corporate policy to prevent teams from deploying Docker images to an environment unless the Docker image was tested in an earlier environment.

c.answer_text: Configure binary authorization policies for the development, staging, and production clusters. Create attestations as part of the continuous integration pipeline.

d.answer_text: Create a Kubernetes admissions controller to prevent the container from starting if it is not approved for usage in the given environment.

hint: To enforce that only tested and approved Docker images are deployed to GKE clusters, especially across different environments, use Binary Authorization with attestations in your CI/CD pipeline.

question_text: You want to allow your operations team to store logs from all the production projects in your Organization, without including logs from other projects. All of the production projects are contained in a folder. You want to ensure that all logs for existing and new production projects are captured automatically. What should you do?

a.answer_text: Create an aggregated export on the Production folder. Set the log sink to be a Cloud Storage bucket in an operations project.

b.answer_text: Create an aggregated export on the Organization resource. Set the log sink to be a Cloud Storage bucket in an operations project.

c.answer_text: Create log exports in the production projects. Set the log sinks to be a Cloud Storage bucket in an operations project.

d.answer_text: Create log exports in the production projects. Set the log sinks to be BigQuery datasets in the production projects, and grant IAM access to the operations team to run queries on the datasets.

hint: For automatic collection of logs from all existing and future projects within a specific environment (e.g., production), configure an aggregated log export at the Folder level.

question_text: Your company recently acquired a company that has infrastructure in Google Cloud. Each company has its own Google Cloud organization. Each company is using a Shared Virtual Private Cloud (VPC) to provide network connectivity for its applications. Some of the subnets used by both companies overlap. In order for both businesses to integrate, the applications need to have private network connectivity. These applications are not on overlapping subnets. You want to provide connectivity with minimal re-engineering. What should you do?

a.answer_text: Set up VPC peering and peer each Shared VPC together.

b.answer_text: Migrate the projects from the acquired company into your company's Google Cloud organization. Re-launch the instances in your companies Shared VPC.

c.answer_text: Set up a Cloud VPN gateway in each Shared VPC and peer Cloud VPNs.

d.answer_text: Configure SSH port forwarding on each application to provide connectivity between applications in the different Shared VPCs.

hint: When integrating two independent GCP organizations or Shared VPCs, especially with potential IP overlap issues, Cloud VPN can bridge the networks with minimal re-engineering.

question_text: Your company has developed a monolithic, 3-tier application to allow external users to upload and share files. The solution cannot be easily enhanced and lacks reliability. The development team would like to re-architect the application to adopt microservices and a fully managed service approach, but they need to convince their leadership that the effort is worthwhile. Which advantage(s) should they highlight to leadership?

a.answer_text: The new approach will be significantly less costly, make it easier to manage the underlying infrastructure, and automatically manage the CI/CD pipelines.

b.answer_text: The monolithic solution can be converted to a container with Docker. The generated container can then be deployed into a Kubernetes cluster.

c.answer_text: The new approach will make it easier to decouple infrastructure from application, develop and release new features, manage the underlying infrastructure, manage CI/CD pipelines and perform A/B testing, and scale the solution if necessary.

d.answer_text: The process can be automated with Migrate for Compute Engine.

hint: Microservice architecture benefits include improved agility, scalability, feature development, and operational efficiencies.

question_text: Your operations team currently stores 10 TB of data in an object storage service from a third-party provider. They want to move this data to a Cloud Storage bucket as quickly as possible, following Google-recommended practices. They want to minimize the cost of this data migration. Which approach should they use?

a.answer_text: Use the gsutil mv command to move the data.

b.answer_text: Use the Storage Transfer Service to move the data.

c.answer_text: Download the data to a Transfer Appliance, and ship it to Google.

d.answer_text: Download the data to the on-premises data center, and upload it to the Cloud Storage bucket.

hint: For large-scale, automated transfers between object storage providers or into Cloud Storage, look for a managed transfer service.

question_text: Your company is planning to upload several important files to Cloud Storage. After the upload is completed, they want to verify that the uploaded content is identical to what they have on-premises. You want to minimize the cost and effort of performing this check. What should you do?

a.answer_text: 1. Use Linux shasum to compute a digest of files you want to upload. 2. Use gsutil -m to upload all the files to Cloud Storage. 3. Use gsutil cp to download the uploaded files. 4. Use Linux shasum to compute a digest of the downloaded files. 5. Compare the hashes.

b.answer_text: 1. Use gsutil -m to upload the files to Cloud Storage. 2. Develop a custom Java application that computes CRC32C hashes. 3. Use gsutil ls -L gs://[YOUR_BUCKET_NAME] to collect CRC32C hashes of the uploaded files. 4. Compare the hashes.

c.answer_text: 1. Use gsutil -m to upload all the files to Cloud Storage. 2. Use gsutil cp to download the uploaded files. 3. Use Linux diff to compare the content of the files.

d.answer_text: 1. Use gsutil -m to upload the files to Cloud Storage. 2. Use gsutil hash -c FILE_NAME to generate CRC32C hashes of all on-premises files. 3. Use gsutil ls -L gs://[YOUR_BUCKET_NAME] to collect CRC32C hashes of the uploaded files. 4. Compare the hashes.

hint: To verify file integrity after upload to Cloud Storage efficiently, leverage checksums that the service can provide without downloading the full data.

question_text: Your company has a Google Cloud project that uses BigQuery for data warehousing. There are some tables that contain personally identifiable information (PII). Only the compliance team may access the PII. The other information in the tables must be available to the data science team. You want to minimize cost and the time it takes to assign appropriate access to the tables. What should you do?

a.answer_text: 1. From the dataset where you have the source data, create views of tables that you want to share, excluding PII. 2. Assign an appropriate project-level IAM role to the members of the data science team. 3. Assign access controls to the dataset that contains the view.

b.answer_text: 1. From the dataset where you have the source data, create materialized views of tables that you want to share, excluding PII. 2. Assign an appropriate project-level IAM role to the members of the data science team. 3. Assign access controls to the dataset that contains the view.

c.answer_text: 1. Create a dataset for the data science team. 2. Create views of tables that you want to share, excluding PII. 3. Assign an appropriate project-level IAM role to the members of the data science team. 4. Assign access controls to the dataset that contains the view. 5. Authorize the view to access the source dataset.

d.answer_text: 1. Create a dataset for the data science team. 2. Create materialized views of tables that you want to share, excluding PII. 3. Assign an appropriate project-level IAM role to the members of the data science team. 4. Assign access controls to the dataset that contains the view. 5. Authorize the view to access the source dataset.

hint: To control access at the column/row level for PII and other data in BigQuery efficiently, consider using authorized views with separate datasets for different teams.

question_text: For this question, refer to the TerramEarth case study. TerramEarth has about 1 petabyte (PB) of vehicle testing data in a private data center. You want to move the data to Cloud Storage for your machine learning team. Currently, a 1-Gbps interconnect link is available for you. The machine learning team wants to start using the data in a month. What should you do?

a.answer_text: Request Transfer Appliances from Google Cloud, export the data to appliances, and return the appliances to Google Cloud.

b.answer_text: Configure the Storage Transfer service from Google Cloud to send the data from your data center to Cloud Storage.

c.answer_text: Make sure there are no other users consuming the 1Gbps link, and use multi-thread transfer to upload the data to Cloud Storage.

d.answer_text: Export files to an encrypted USB device, send the device to Google Cloud, and request an import of the data to Cloud Storage.

hint: For very large datasets (PBs) with a tight timeline for transfer to Cloud, a physical data transfer service like Transfer Appliance is often faster than network-based options, especially with limited bandwidth.

question_text: You are deploying an application to Google Cloud. The application is part of a system. The application in Google Cloud must communicate over a private network with applications in a non-Google Cloud environment. The expected average throughput is 200 kbps. The business requires: ✑ as close to 100% system availability as possible ✑ cost optimization You need to design the connectivity between the locations to meet the business requirements. What should you provision?

a.answer_text: An HA Cloud VPN gateway connected with two tunnels to an on-premises VPN gateway

b.answer_text: Two Classic Cloud VPN gateways connected to two on-premises VPN gateways Configure each Classic Cloud VPN gateway to have two tunnels, each connected to different on-premises VPN gateways

c.answer_text: Two HA Cloud VPN gateways connected to two on-premises VPN gateways Configure each HA Cloud VPN gateway to have two tunnels, each connected to different on-premises VPN gateways

d.answer_text: A single Cloud VPN gateway connected to an on-premises VPN gateway

hint: For high availability and cost optimization for specific throughput requirements, HA Cloud VPN offers redundant tunnels from a single gateway, which can be more cost-effective than multiple full VPN gateways.

question_text: The operations team in your company wants to save Cloud VPN log events for one year. You need to configure the cloud infrastructure to save the logs. What should you do?

a.answer_text: Set up a filter in Cloud Logging and a Cloud Storage bucket as an export target for the logs you want to save.

b.answer_text: Enable the Compute Engine API, and then enable logging on the firewall rules that match the traffic you want to save.

c.answer_text: Set up a Cloud Logging Dashboard titled Cloud VPN Logs, and then add a chart that queries for the VPN metrics over a one-year time period.

d.answer_text: Set up a filter in Cloud Logging and a topic in Pub/Sub to publish the logs.

hint: For long-term log retention beyond Cloud Logging's default retention, export relevant logs to Cloud Storage.

question_text: You are managing several projects on Google Cloud and need to interact on a daily basis with BigQuery, Bigtable, and Kubernetes Engine using the gcloud CL tool. You are travelling a lot and work on different workstations during the week. You want to avoid having to manage the gcloud CLI manually. What should you do?

a.answer_text: Use Google Cloud Shell in the Google Cloud Console to interact with Google Cloud.

b.answer_text: Create a Compute Engine instance and install gcloud on the instance. Connect to this instance via SSH to always use the same gcloud installation when interacting with Google Cloud.

c.answer_text: Install gcloud on all of your workstations. Run the command gcloud components auto-update on each workstation

d.answer_text: Use a package manager to install gcloud on your workstations instead of installing it manually.

hint: To avoid local CLI management and have a consistent environment for interacting with GCP services from any location, use a web-based shell environment pre-configured with gcloud tools.

question_text: You are developing a globally scaled frontend for a legacy streaming backend data API. This API expects events in strict chronological order with no repeat data for proper processing. Which products should you deploy to ensure guaranteed-once FIFO (first-in, first-out) delivery of data?

a.answer_text: Cloud Pub/Sub alone

b.answer_text: Cloud Pub/Sub to Cloud Dataflow

c.answer_text: Cloud Pub/Sub to Stackdriver

d.answer_text: Cloud Pub/Sub to Cloud SQL

hint: While Pub/Sub offers at-least-once delivery, to achieve strict FIFO and guaranteed-once semantics, especially with complex processing requirements, consider a robust stream processing engine.

question_text: Your company has a Kubernetes application that pulls messages from Pub/Sub and stores them in Filestore. Because the application is simple, it was deployed as a single pod. The infrastructure team has analyzed Pub/Sub metrics and discovered that the application cannot process the messages in real time. Most of them wait for minutes before being processed. You need to scale the elaboration process that is I/O-intensive. What should you do?

a.answer_text: Use kubectl autoscale deployment APP_NAME --max 6 --min 2 --cpu-percent 50 to configure Kubernetes autoscaling deployment.

b.answer_text: Configure a Kubernetes autoscaling deployment based on the subscription/push_request_latencies metric.

c.answer_text: Use the --enable-autoscaling flag when you create the Kubernetes cluster.

d.answer_text: Configure a Kubernetes autoscaling deployment based on the subscription/num_undelivered_messages metric.

hint: For scaling message-processing applications in Kubernetes, use the Horizontal Pod Autoscaler (HPA) and base its scaling decisions on a metric directly reflecting the message backlog.
